section.title: Present perfect simple
section.sectiontitle: We use the Present perfect to connect the past to the present in some way: for example, we use it to talk about an action which started in the past and continues to the present.
section.text1: I started playing tennis when I was twelve and I still play now.
section.text1a: I've played tennis since I was twelve.
section.text2: I met her many years ago and I still know her now.
section.sectiontitle2: We also use the Present perfect simple to talk about a completed action which happened in a period including now. We often don't say exactly when the action happened.
section.text3: It happened this week and it's still this week. We don't say exactly when in the week:
section.text4: It happened in my life up to now. We don't say exactly when.

section.title: Present perfect simple
section.sectiontitle: We often use the Present perfect simple to talk about a recent completed action. The results of this action are important now.
section.text1: He lost his keys at some time in the recent past. It's important now because he's looking for them.
section.text2: I'm waiting for a taxi. My friend gives me the news.
section.sectiontitle2: In the positive, we use have/has + past participle and in the negative have/has + not + past participle.

section.title: Present perfect simple
section.sectiontitle: In the question, we use have/has + subject + past participle.
section.text1a: Have you been to Argentina? Yes, I have.
section.text2a: Has she worked here long? No, she hasn't.
section.sectiontitle2: We often use the Present perfect simple with all my life, this week/month/year, so far, already, yet, just, ever.
section.text3: We usually use ever in questions to ask about experience in your life.
section.text4: We use yet in questions and negatives to talk about actions that haven't happened in the past, but we think could happen in the future.
